comments.body: Is distributing the right term here? I thought it was publishing as the activity a collection owner does. Just wondering if someon would search 'how do I distribute my collection' vs 'how do I publish my collection' ? I also don't see anything in official AH documentation or marketing details that calls it a distribution server?

Yeah, I debated about that. Current thinking is that "distributing" includes both creating the tarball and publishing the tarball to Galaxy/AH. I made sure the first paragraph includes both terms. Looking at it again, though, I see that I don't mention packaging it up to create the tarball . . . I'll add a sentence about that.
oh, it's there, in the "three major steps" section . . . phew

Do you think we should advertise this since passing secrets on cmdline may lead to exposing them to others on the system? or you might want to add a line saying that "this is the available but not recommended method" or something...
btw, https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/developing_collections_distributing.html#specifying-your-api-token-with-the-token-argument discusses this.

In general I don't think obfuscating or "not advertising" the way the tool works is a great idea.  If we truly believe that no one should use the `--token` feature we should remove it from the code base.  I would assume that tons of employees are using this feature from their laptops as it speeds up development and testing.  I don't mind adding some more info here about security, but I imagine this is like every other tool out there where tokens are used on the command line.
Agree. While you are here, can you add that note then?
@Akasurde maybe link to that as well... (e.g. link there for another example https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/dev_guide/developing_collections_distributing.html#specifying-your-api-token)
@Akasurde - I'm working on a separate PR to add anchors in that file. Once I have that, all include the link above as well. I think Sean has had enough rst fun for one day ;-)

comments.body: The #. was showing up as #. in the actual documentation. Should these not be replaced with a numbered list?

This PR fixes the problem by adding the blank line, see http://docs.testing.ansible.com/ansible-core/devel/dev_guide/developing_collections_distributing.html.
